abstract.p: Americans for Medical Progress president Jacquie Calnan letter on Oct 15 article on deal between Agriculture Department and arm of Anti-Vivisection Society that commits department to extend protection of Animal Welfare Act to many more animals; says research with laboratory animals is necessary component of quest to improve quality of our lives through medical progress

block.p: Your Oct. 15 Week in Review article accurately describes the humane care that laboratory animals, including rats and mice, receive in our nation's biomedical research facilities and then asks why the group Alternatives Research and Development Foundation would sue to have rats and mice covered under the Animal Welfare Act.

The answer is simple. Its ultimate goal is to halt all biomedical research with animals. Its parent organization, the American Anti-Vivisection Society, describes itself as an ''animal rights organization whose objective is to end experimentation on animals in education, science and research.''

Your Oct. 15 Week in Review article accurately describes the humane care that laboratory animals, including rats and mice, receive in our nation's biomedical research facilities and then asks why the group Alternatives Research and Development Foundation would sue to have rats and mice covered under the Animal Welfare Act.

The answer is simple. Its ultimate goal is to halt all biomedical research with animals. Its parent organization, the American Anti-Vivisection Society, describes itself as an ''animal rights organization whose objective is to end experimentation on animals in education, science and research.''
Yet research with laboratory animals is, and for the foreseeable future must remain, a necessary component of the quest to improve the quality of our lives through medical progress.
JACQUIE CALNAN President Americans for Medical Progress Alexandria, Va., Oct. 17, 2000
